PostValue.explanation: This is a high-utility advocacy/roundup post for the EA/animal-welfare subset: it synthesizes the case that trillions of invertebrates plausibly suffer, points to extremely cost‑effective interventions (Shrimp Welfare Project, insect/fish research, ACE movement grants, GiveWell-relevant arguments) and could shift donor dollars and regulatory attention. It isn’t foundational theory or novel empirical proof, but if its claims are accepted it meaningfully changes philanthropic priorities and could avert enormous amounts of suffering — hence substantial importance for EAs. For general humanity it’s of modest importance: potentially influential for food/farming policy and niche philanthropy, but not central to broad human concerns and depends on contested empirical and ethical premises.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Stop pretending precision where there’s massive uncertainty. The post leans heavily on single-point estimates (e.g. “19% as intensely as humans,” “a dollar prevents tens of thousands of shrimp,” “prevents as much agony as 3,000 tortured people”) without showing how sensitive the conclusions are to those assumptions. That will alienate EA readers. Actionable fix: add a short sensitivity / uncertainty paragraph (or a simple table) showing how your main claims change if sentience/intensity estimates are 5× lower or higher, and cite peer‑reviewed sources where possible rather than a single Google Doc. Replace absolute-sounding one-liners with ranges or confidence qualifiers.  

2) Address the biggest plausible counterarguments and downside risks up front. You skip over important objections that EA readers will expect: moral-status objections (why treat insect/shrimp suffering as morally weighty as human suffering?), ecological and system-level side effects (could welfare improvements increase demand/production and backfire? could interventions disrupt ecosystems?), and implementation risks (greenwashing, certification capture, enforcement failure). Actionable fix: add a brief “Main objections” section that (a) states these counterarguments fairly, (b) gives short replies or points to evidence, and (c) flags open questions where further research is needed. This keeps the piece credible and saves readers’ time.  

3) Tone and framing issues hurt credibility. Some analogies and phrasing (e.g. comparing shrimp farms to Khmer Rouge Cambodia, heavily emotive language) read as hyperbolic and may undermine the charitable-analytics case you’re trying to make. Also disclose incentives/relationships clearly (you offer paid subscriptions for donations, you crosspost and previously raised money). Actionable fix: moderate extreme analogies, use more measured language in headline claims, and add a clear disclosure of any personal incentives/affiliations and whether you have any conflicts of interest or referral links.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback targets several real and important weaknesses: overstated single‑point estimates without sensitivity/uncertainty, omission of the main counterarguments and system‑level downsides EA readers will expect, and credibility‑hurting tone and disclosure issues. Fixing these would materially improve the post’s persuasiveness and avoid obvious 'own goals' (e.g. dramatic numeric claims that collapse under reasonable parameter changes, emotive analogies that alienate skeptics, and unclear incentives). The recommended fixes are practical and can be implemented briefly (a sensitivity paragraph, a short 'main objections' and response section, and a disclosure), so the advice is high‑impact without unduly lengthening the piece.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: Pseudonymous/niche online author with a small or occasional presence in EA/rationalist spaces rather than a well-known figure; not a frequent speaker or central community leader and has no notable mainstream/global visibility. Identification is uncertain due to pseudonymity.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is generally clear and well-structured — informative headings, concrete examples, and many links make the argument easy to follow. Strengths include a logical case for why neglected invertebrates matter and a clear donor-focused section listing organizations and actions. Weaknesses are verbosity and some repetition, occasional rhetorical excesses and hyperbole that may distract, minor organizational inconsistencies (heading/numbering and mixed tones), and some dense paragraphs that could be tightened for readers skimming for key takeaways.

PostNovelty.explanation: For an EA/animal-welfare audience the post contains little genuinely new: the core arguments for taking invertebrate suffering seriously, the cited research groups (Rethink Priorities, ACE movement grants, Shrimp Welfare Project, ALI, etc.), and cost‑effectiveness framing are already familiar. The most novel bits for insiders are some specific quantitative claims (e.g. the 19% suffering estimate) and the explicit recommendation to route impact via ACE Movement Grants and particular small orgs. For the general educated public the piece is moderately novel: many people haven’t considered the scale of invertebrate suffering, the argument that small donations buy massive reductions in agony, or the idea that disease interventions (e.g. malaria prevention) can be defended partly as reducing insect lives. Those connections and the emphasis on shrimp/insect welfare will be new or surprising to many non‑specialists.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post presents a clear, logically structured argument (plausible sentience → large aggregate suffering → high leverage interventions) and cites reputable EA-aligned organizations (ACE, Rethink Priorities), published investigations, and concrete interventions (stunners, policy wins). The author also notes uncertainty about sentience. Weaknesses: Key quantitative claims (e.g., shrimp suffer 19% as intensely as humans; dollars preventing ‘thousands of tortures’) rest on contested, non‑peer‑reviewed or model‑dependent estimates and large scaling assumptions that are not sufficiently qualified. Moral premises (how to weigh tiny/short lives against human suffering) are assumed rather than defended for skeptical readers. Evidence is relevant but often indirect, uncertain, or reliant on single reports and EA‑community sources rather than broad, converging empirical validation. Overall, the thesis is plausible and usefully supported, but the magnitude claims and cost‑effectiveness estimates carry substantial uncertainty and would benefit from more rigorous, transparent sensitivity analysis and independent corroboration.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most major empirical claims in the post are supported by reliable sources, but several quantitative estimates are model-dependent and uncertain. Strongly supported claims: (a) shrimp are extremely numerous (hundreds of billions farmed annually) and pre‑slaughter mortality is very high (~~50%); Rethink Priorities and Faunalytics document ~230 billion shrimp alive on farms at a time, ~440 billion slaughtered/year and ~50% pre‑slaughter mortality. (b) Shrimp Welfare Project is an active, ACE‑reviewed charity with stated impact estimates in the billions of shrimp helped annually (their site and ACE reports document ~2.7–3.9 billion helped depending on accounting). (c) Aquatic Life Institute supported policy/company changes (e.g., helping push for California’s octopus‑farming ban and advising on Hilton/Tesco crustacean policies). (d) ACE Movement Grants did fund groups such as the Insect Welfare Research Society. (e) Investigations of Scottish salmon farms and mass mortalities have been widely reported (Salmon Media Hub, The Ferret, The Guardian, etc.). Supported but model‑dependent / uncertain claims: the author’s specific welfare‑intensity numbers (e.g., “shrimp suffer 19% as intensely as humans; bees 15%; carp 18%”) are not a settled consensus—Rethink Priorities’ welfare‑range work gives much lower central estimates for shrimp (median ~0.031 in one published welfare‑range model) though other modeling choices can yield higher point estimates; therefore the exact percent figures cited are plausible as one model’s outputs but not broadly established. The claim that a single dollar prevents “tens of thousands” of shrimp depends on how impact is counted (SWP reports ~1,100–2,100 shrimps helped per $ vs. other ways of counting give larger multipliers), so those per‑dollar conversions are highly sensitive to assumptions. Overall: many core factual claims (scale of shrimp farming; high mortality; existence and activities of listed orgs; ACE funding) are well‑verified; specific numeric welfare‑weighting and extremely large per‑dollar conversions are plausible under particular models but uncertain and should be treated as estimate‑dependent.
sources: Rethink Priorities — Welfare considerations for farmed shrimp (Shrimp Welfare Sequence) (Dec 2023 / 2024 report pages).
Faunalytics — "Three Numbers That Make The Case For Shrimp Welfare" (Hannah McKay, Oct 9, 2024).
Shrimp Welfare Project — (Shr)Impact / Humane Slaughter Initiative and organizational pages (site impact numbers, stunner program).
Animal Charity Evaluators — Movement Grants / Shrimp Welfare Project charity review and Recommended Charity Fund update (ACE blog & charity review pages).
Aquatic Life Institute (ALI) — blog on CA octopus ban & ALI work; ALI pages on crustacean recommendations and Hilton/Tesco policy support.
News coverage of California octopus‑farming ban (e.g., Food & Wine, Oct 2024) confirming state law AB 3162.
Hilton Foods / trade press reporting (Fish Farmer, The Fish Site, Hilton Foods corporate pages) on Hilton's crustacean welfare policy (2024).
Rethink Priorities — Welfare Range Estimates (EA Forum / RP pages) and related welfare‑range discussion (shows much lower median for shrimp in one published model).
Independent modeling / welfare‑range variants (public analyses collecting different modeling choices; example aggregation on EA Forum and external summaries).
Salmon Media Hub (SalmonMediaHub.org) and investigative coverage (The Ferret, The Guardian, Times) documenting undercover investigations and mass salmon mortalities / escapes in Scotland.
Brian Tomasik / Reducing‑Suffering.org — cost‑effectiveness estimates for reducing insect suffering, including malaria/AMF calculations (e.g., estimates of insect‑years prevented per $).
Science Advances / academic coverage on aquaculture and welfare (context on numbers of individuals farmed across aquaculture).
